Assessment  undertaken  for  each  of  the  investment  components  under  the 
Project. A regional environmental impact assessment (REIA) was 
undertaken  for  Southern  Baiyin  industrial  zone  (SBIZ).  The

Project Description  Baiyin  city  (Baiyin)  is  a  medium-sized  city  located  in  Gansu 
province. The city was established in 1950s under the planned 
economy mainly to support copper mining production. Baiyin used 
to be the top copper miner of the PRC, accounting for one third of 
the national production. After continued exploitation, the copper 
mines in Baiyin had been exhausted and were abandoned. Mining 
of  the  other  associated  minerals  is  also  on a  declining  trend. 
Baiyin is one of the 18 mining cities classified by the Government 
as resource-exhausted. Under the 11th Five- Year Program (FYP) 
for 2006–2010, the Government has decided to provide special 
support, as a national priority, for the resource-exhausted mining 
cities to facilitate their economic transformation. 
 
The  Project  will  provide  support  to  facilitate  economic 
transformation  in  Baiyin  by  strengthening  urban  services  and 
infrastructure, and promoting capacity development. The Project 
has five components: (i) Southern Baiyin infrastructure, (ii) Baiyin 
road improvements, (iii) Pingchuan road improvements, (iv) Baiyin 
district  heating  services,  and  (v)  capacity  cevelopment  and 
institutional strengthening. The Project is consistent with ADB’s 
Urban Sector Strategy and the strategic focus of ADB operation in 
PRC as identified and discussed with the Government during the 
ongoing country partnership strategy consultation process. All the 
investment  components  under  the  project  are  included  in  the 
Baiyin Urban Development Master Plan (2001–2020) endorsed by 
the Baiyin People’s Congress.

ii   
Rationale  Baiyin is one of the 18 mining cities classified by the Government 
as resource-exhausted. In PRC, Baiyin stands for a new model of 
economic transformation from a resource-exhausted mining city 
into a new industrial center through technology upgrading and 
extension, and diversification of the existing production chains. 
ADB  involvement  in  the  Project  will  provide  not  only  financial 
support needed to accelerate economic transformation, but also 
international knowledge and policy advice for the Baiyin municipal 
government  (BMG)  to  help  ensure  that  the  economic 
transformation  will  be  accomplished  in  a  sustainable  and 
environment-friendly manner. The Project will also play a role in 
demonstrating  economic  transformation  for  other  resource-
exhausted mining cities. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project will be the sustainable and environment- 
friendly urban development of Baiyin. The outcome will be the 
facilitated economic transformation and improved quality of life in 
Baiyin.

including taxes and duties of $4.7 million.

The Government has requested ADB to provide a loan of $80 
million to finance 49.5% of the project cost, including financing 
charges  during  construction.  The  Government  will  finance  the 
balance through a combination of BMG and Pingchuan district 
government (PDG) budget resources, domestic loans from PRC 
banks,  and  equity  investment  from  Minyue  District  Heating 
Corporation (MDHC). 
   
The ADB loan of $80 million will be provided from the ordinary 
capital  resources  under  its  London  interbank  offered  rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have a 25-year term 
including a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and such other terms 
and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements.

As the end-borrowers BMG, PDG, and MDHC will assume, for

Implementation  BMG has established a project leading group (PLG), headed by 
Arrangements  the mayor to direct the Project and provide policy guidance during 
project implementation. Under the PLG, BMG has set up a project 
management office (PMO) to coordinate the implementation of 
project  activities  on  behalf  of  BMG.  The  PMO  will  (i)  ensure 
adequate  interdepartmental  and  interagency  coordination,  (ii) 
monitor  the  progress  of  project  implementation,  and  (iii) 
coordinate communication with ADB and the agencies concerned. 
 
There are four IAs for the Project: (i) Baiyin High-Tech Industrial 
Park  (BHTIP)  Management  Commission,  responsible  for 
implementing the Southern Baiyin infrastructure component; (ii) 
Baiyin  City  Construction  Bureau  (BCCB),  responsible  for 
implementing the Baiyin road improvements component; (iii) PDG, 
responsible for implementing the Pingchuan road improvements 
component;  and  (iv)  MDHC,  responsible  for  implementing  the 
district heating services component. Among the four, BHTIP and 
BCCB are part of the BMG. PDG is a local government unit under 
the jurisdiction of BMG. MDHC is a state share-controlled public-
private  corporation.  A  project  implementation  unit  will  be 
established in each IA and will report to the respective IA for 
undertaking detailed implementation activities. 
   
Procurement  All  procurement  of  goods  and  works  shall  be  carried  out  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  International  competitive  bidding, 
national competitive bidding, or shopping procedures will be used, 
depending on the circumstances of each contract package.

iv   
Consulting Services  About 18 person-months of international and 116 person-months 
of national consulting services will be provided for the capacity 
development  and  institutional  strengthening  component.  The 
consultants  will  help  BMG  (i)  design  and  establish  an 
environmental management system for the SBIZ, (ii) develop a 
geographic information system-based urban management system 
to improve urban planning and road and bridge management, and 
(iii)  provide  project  management  and  construction  supervision 
support.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). 
   
Project Benefits and  The  Project  will  directly  benefit  more  than  475,000  urban 
Beneficiaries  presidents  in  the  project  areas  through  construction  of  urban 
infrastructure for economic transformation, improved urban roads, 
and expanded and enhanced district heating supply. The Project 
will provide the infrastructure and consulting service inputs to help 
BMG manage and accomplish the economic transformation in a 
sustainable and environment-friendly manner. When completed, 
the SBIZ is expected to provide more than 5,400 permanent jobs 
for skilled laborers whose jobs are being affected by the decline of 
the mining resources.  
 
Through the district heating services component, the Project will 
replace 63 small polluting coal-fire heating boilers with a more 
efficient  and  environment-friendly  centralized  district  heating 
system. By the year 2015, the heating service area will expand by 
2.6 million square meters and benefit about 20,000 households 
among whom about 10% are low-income families. The district 
heating services component will also help reduce the emission of 
sulfur dioxide by 185 tons per year, reduce consumption of coal 
by 5,700 tons per year, and improve public health and indoor air 
quality by eliminating numerous indoor coal-burning stoves and 
switching to district heating, particularly for the poor.  
 
The road improvement components will build up the basic urban 
road frameworks in the two urban centers of Baiyin—Baiyin and 
Pingchuan districts―to meet their long-term development needs. 
The improved road systems will help strengthen public transport 
service  and  improve  road  safety  by  providing  public  transport 
facilities, increasing bus lines, and reducing the road accident 
fatalities in 2011 by about 10% from the 2005 baseline. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  does  not  have  any  unusual  technical  risks. 
Conventional  engineering  designs  and  technology  with  proven 
records of reliable performance are adopted for all the investment 
components. Consulting services will be provided to support the 
PMO and IAs to ensure timely implementation of the Project in 
accordance with the design requirements and quality standards.

v
The risk may arise from the induced environmental impact due to 
the intensified industrial activities in the SBIZ. To mitigate the risk 
in a systematic manner, BMG has undertaken a REIA to assess 
the environmental impact from the industrial activities in both the 
existing BHTIP and the SBIZ to be developed under the Project. 
An environmental management plan (EMP) has been developed 
under the REIA to mitigate the identified environmental risks. In 
addition to the EMP, consulting services will be provided to help 
BMG design and introduce an urban environmental management 
system to ensure that the urban economic transformation will be 
conducted and accomplished in a sustainable and environment- 
friendly manner.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Gansu Baiyin Urban Development Project. 
 
2.  The Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help strengthen the 
urban  sustainability  of  Baiyin  City  (Baiyin)  in  Gansu  province,  by  facilitating  the  economic 
transformation of this resource-exhausted mining city. The Project is consistent with ADB’s 
Medium-Term Strategy (2006-2008) and Urban Sector Strategy.1 This report is based on the 
results  of  the  Loan  Appraisal  Mission,  as  well  as  discussions  with  the  central  and  local 
governments, relevant agencies, and community organizations.2 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Since the PRC initiated economic reforms in 1978, rapid urbanization has accompanied 
significant economic progress. The urban population has nearly tripled from about 190 million in 
1980 to more than 560 million in 2005, and now accounts for more than 43% of the national 
population. The Government’s agenda for economic reform and social development aims to 
accelerate urbanization and to achieve a balanced development of the large and medium-sized 
cities as well as the small cities and towns. Consequently, the urban population is expected to 
reach 47% of the total population by 2010, thereby increasing the demand for urban services.3 
The increasing urban population, industrialization, and economic development are straining the 
overloaded infrastructure, and contributing to widespread pollution and environmental threats in 
PRC  cities.  Without  significant  investment,  the  urban  environment  will  degrade,  economic 
development will be encumbered, and the people’s quality of life will deteriorate. 
 
4.  Within the urban sector, PRC has identified 118 cities that were developed, depending 
on mining of particular natural resources of their localities. They account for 18% of the total 
cities in the PRC and provide livelihood for a total urban population of 154 million. Many of these 
mining cities are located in the remote and less developed western PRC. They share a very 
similar history and common characteristics: (i) they were established in the 1950s or 1960s 
under the planned economy with sole responsibility for supporting mining production, with little 
attention  given  to  urban  sustainability;  (ii)  in  the  past,  the  state  through  central  planning 
allocated all their outputs  for national development, leaving little resources for local investments 
on urban development; and (iii) the natural resources they depend on are now diminishing or 
are being exhausted after decades of mining production. As a consequence, most of these 
mining  cities  have  encountered  great  difficulties  in  the  urbanization  process  due  to  their 
remoteness, their imbalanced economic structures, their limited financial capacity, their poor 
urban infrastructure, and their limited development prospects. Of those cities, 47 are under 
threat of resource exhaustion, and 18 are classified as resource-exhausted cities, thereby 
posing a special challenge to urbanization in the PRC.

5.  Experience  worldwide  indicates  that  resource-dependent  mining  cities  may  have 
different options in response to a diminishing mining resource. These include abandoning the 
town  when  mining  becomes  uneconomical,  converting  the  abandoned  mines  and  mining 
facilities  into  a  museum  or  cultural  heritage  sites  that  may  have  an  educational  and 
entertainment function while providing livelihood for a small population, or developing alternative 
industries in the nonmining sectors as the new engine for continued growth and sustainable 
development. Given their sizes and the populations they support, most of these mining cities in 
the PRC would have to explore the possibilities to develop alternative industries for sustainable 
development.  Under  the  11th  Five-Year  Program  (FYP)  for  National  Economic  and  Social 
Development  (2006–2010),  the  Government  has  decided  to  provide  special  support,  as  a 
national priority, for these resource-exhausted cities to facilitate their economic transformation 
from the traditional mining bases established under the planned economy into dynamic and 
sustainable urban centers under a market economy. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  Project Background. Baiyin is a medium-sized city in Gansu province, one of the 12 
less developed western provinces and autonomous regions targeted by the Government for 
support under the National Strategy for Development of the West (NSDW). Like many other 
mining cities, Baiyin was established in the 1950s under the planned economy, mainly to 
support the development and production of Baiyin Nonferrous Metal Corporation (BNMC), which 
used to be the PRC’s top copper mine, accounting for about one third of national copper 
production. Over the past 50 years, Baiyin has been developed into an important national center 
for nonferrous metal mining, smelting, and initial processing, and an energy and chemical 
production center of Gansu province. Baiyin now covers a total land area of 21,158 square 
kilometers (km2) and has a population of 1.75 million (2005). Most of the land under the 
jurisdiction of the Baiyin municipal government (BMG) are uncultivated and undeveloped arid 
land without any human settlement. Baiyin has two urban districts: (i) Baiyin district, which has a 
land area of 1,373 km2, a population of about 279,000, and where the BMG is seated; and (ii) 
Pingchuan district with a land area of 2,106 km2 and a population of about 196,300. The two 
urban districts are about 78 kilometers (km) apart. They are connected by a newly constructed 
expressway that is well-integrated with the surrounding national and provincial expressway 
systems, most of which have been built as part of the NSDW.  
 
7.  Rapid development of the basic infrastructures in the west, supported under the NSDW 
over the past few years, has provided Baiyin, which used to be geographically remote and 
relatively isolated, with the basic means to integrate itself with the national and world market 
through  road,  railway,  air  transport,  and  telecommunication  services.  Investors  have  been 
attracted to this mining city by its advantages including adequate supply of skilled labors, low-
cost land, and its easy access to both market and resources. Such advantages have resulted in 
a steady gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaging 11.4% a year during the 10th FYP 
period (2001–2005) and a reduction in the proportion of the people living below the government 
poverty line from 12.4% to 10.8%.    
 
8.  Along with continued growth of mining production, the carrying capacity of Baiyin’s urban 
infrastructure  has  been  stretched  to  its  limit,  leading  to  severe  environmental  and  social 
development problems that affect not only the living standards of the city dwellers but also its 
development prospects. The most acute challenge to future development of Baiyin is the urgent 
need to diversify its economic base in view of the diminishing mining resources after decades of 
exploitation.  The  two  main  copper  mines  of  BNMC  have  already  been  exhausted  and 
abandoned.  Mining  of  the  other  associated  minerals  is  also  on  the  decline,  with  closure

projected in less than two decades. Thousands of highly skilled workers are looking for new 
employment opportunities to survive.  
 
9.  To  set  the  direction  for  long-term  development  of  Baiyin,  BMG  conducted  a 
comprehensive study in 2001 to formulate the Baiyin Urban Development Master Plan (2001–
2020). By careful examination of the local advantages, the study has identified the potential of 
the city to develop into a diversified economic center for sustained growth through economic 
transformation.  Based  on  the  master  plan,  BMG  has  identified  nonferrous  metal  industry, 
electricity power, coal mining, and chemical industry―four leading industries―as the engines 
for sustained economic growth, which are further supported by eight supporting industries 
including rare earth, fine chemical, new energy, agroprocessing, and tourism (Appendix 2). 
 
10.  BMG has recognized that success in economic transformation needs the joint effort of 
the public and private sectors and should be based on local advantages and market forces. In 
this context, BMG has developed a partnership with the enterprises and industrial investors 
through  which  BMG  will  make  an  initial  investment  (including  providing  the  basic  public 
infrastructure  and  the  industrial  land)  to  provide  an  enabling  environment  for  economic 
transformation, while the enterprises and the industrial investors will make industrial investment 
to upgrade technology and to diversify and extend the existing production chains. Through this 
mechanism, with support from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, BMG has achieved initial 
success in establishing the Baiyin High-Tech Industrial Park (BHTIP) as the platform to foster 
economic  diversification  and  transformation.  Since  2003,  the  BHTIP  has  attracted  43  new 
enterprises, most of which are privately owned or jointly owned by the public and private 
investors, that have made $436 million in investments and created 1,850 permanent jobs. Given 
the initial success of the BHTIP, a pipeline of new applicant enterprises has been developed 
waiting for new industrial land. Encouraged by the promising potential, BMG has decided to 
develop  the  Southern  Baiyin  industrial  zone  (SBIZ)  in  accordance  with  the  Baiyin  Urban 
Development Master Plan (2001–2020). The SBIZ has an approved land area of 14.05 km2 
comprising the BHTIP (8.05 km2) and another 6 km2 of new industrial land to be developed 
under the Project. The SBIZ is expected to be the home of the extended industrial production 
chains in the fields of nonferrous metal materials, fine chemicals, new energy materials, and 
agroprocessing. 
 
11.  In addition, BMG has decided to make further investments to strengthen and upgrade 
the basic urban infrastructure of the city, particularly to strengthen the road systems in the two 
urban districts and to expand the district heating service in Baiyin district. The investments in the 
road systems will help the two urban districts to each complete a basic urban road framework to 
support its long term urban development needs up to 2030. Heating is one of the essential 
social services during winter in northern PRC. The investment for expanding the district heating 
service will significantly improve the quality of life of the people of Baiyin district by providing 
reliable  and  cleaner  heating  service  through  a  centralized  district  heating  system.  The 
centralized system will replace the unreliable, low-efficiency, and polluting small community 
coal-fire heating boilers, which are a major source of air pollution during winter. 
 
12.  Project Rationale. Resource dependent mining cities established under the planned 
economy form a special vulnerable group of cities in the rapid urbanization process of the PRC. 
An established national priority under the 11th FYP is to provide special support for these 
mining cities to facilitate their economic transformation. Baiyin is one of the 18 cities classified 
by the Government as resource-exhausted. In the PRC, Baiyin stands for a new model of 
economic transformation from a resource-exhausted mining city into a new industrial center 
through  a  well  functioning  public  and  private  partnership  for  technology  upgrading  and

4 
extension,  and  diversification  of  the  existing  production  chains.  The  Project  will  serve  a 
demonstration role for economic transformation of the other resource-exhausted mining cities. 
More detailed analyses of PRC urbanization and Baiyin’s strategy for economic transformation 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The Project is consistent with ADB’s Urban Sector Strategy and the strategic focus of 
ADB operations in PRC as identified and discussed with the Government during the ongoing 
country partnership strategy consultation process. All the investment components of the Project 
are included in the Baiyin Urban Development Master Plan (2001-2020) endorsed by the Baiyin 
People’s Congress. ADB involvement in the Project will provide not only the financial support 
needed to accelerate economic transformation, but also international knowledge and policy 
advice for BMG to help ensure that the economic transformation will be accomplished in a 
sustainable and environmentally friendly manner.    
 
14.  Policy Dialogue. The integrated nature of the Project enables ADB to further its ongoing 
policy dialogue with the Government on urban development issues, particularly on the following 
project-related issues: (i) sustainable urban development and environmental management, (ii) 
integrated urban transport planning and management, and (iii) heating service reforms.  
 
15.  Given its decades-long copper mining background, Baiyin is known as one of the major 
industrial polluters in western PRC. With financing support from the central and provincial 
governments, BMG has undertaken many initiatives to address the environmental concerns. 
Details  of  the  domestically  funded  environmental  improvement  projects  in  Baiyin  are  in 
Appendix  3.  The  ongoing  economic  transformation  has  provided  the  city  with  a  unique 
opportunity to diversify its economy, away from highly polluting industries. It is important that the 
economic transformation be managed and accomplished in a sustainable and environment- 
friendly manner, to build a clean and environment-friendly new Baiyin. In this context, BMG has 
undertaken the initiative to conduct a regional environmental impact assessment (REIA) for 
SBIZ covering both the existing BHTIP and the new industrial land to be developed under the 
Project to assess the potential environmental risks and introduce, under an environmental 
management plan (EMP), appropriate mitigation measures. One special focus of policy dialogue 
under the Project is on reviewing the adequacy of the proposed EMP and introducing an 
effective  environmental  management  system  (EMS)  to  ensure  timely  and  effective 
implementation of the EMP. 
 
16.  The  urban  transport  sector  in  the  PRC  is  generally  constrained  by  a  fragmented 
institutional system, under which urban planning, road construction and maintenance, transport 
service, vehicle emission control, and traffic management are managed by different agencies 
with limited cooperation and interagency coordination. In some cities, these institutional barriers 
have  significantly  constrained  the  emergence  of  integrated  urban  planning  and  transport 
management.  BMG  has  made  good  progress  in  resolving  this  problem.  An  interagency 
committee for transport and road safety has been established under the leadership of the 
mayor. Policy dialogue on the urban transport issues is focused mainly on improving public 
transport  service  and  road  safety  as  well  as  further  strengthening  enforcement  of  vehicle 
emission control.     
 
17.  ADB has been active in promoting heating service reforms in the PRC. Its efforts include 
to (i) promote centralized district heating in cities to improve energy efficiency and reduce air 
pollution,  (ii)  introduce  urban  heating  tariff  reforms,  (iii)  encourage  the  private  sector  to 
participate in service provision, and (iv) ensure that low-income families have access to the

5 
improved  heating  service.4 Under  the  Project,  63  low-efficiency  and  highly  polluting  small 
community boilers will be replaced by a centralized district heating system with significant 
energy conservation effect and environmental benefits. The expanded district heating service 
will be provided by the Minyue District Heating Corporation (MDHC), a state share-controlled 
company that won the concession for providing district heating service for west Baiyin district 
through open competition in 2005. Unlike the traditional government-run utilities in many other 
cities, which are suffering from obsolete equipment and redundant workers, MDHC is operated 
by a team of professional and skilled laborers at a low cost with very high operational efficiency. 
Policy dialogue in the heating sector under the Project is focused on ensuring access of low-
income families to the improved heating service.  
 
18.  External  Assistance. The Project will be the first urban development project to be 
funded  by  a  multilateral  development  bank  in  Gansu  province.  Following  the  smooth 
implementation of the project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for the Project, the Gansu 
provincial government (GPG) requested, through the Government, another loan of $150 million 
from ADB for strengthening and upgrading the urban transport system in Lanzhou, the capital 
city of Gansu province. The project preparatory TA and the proposed loan for this second urban 
development project in Gansu province are programmed for 2007 and 2009, respectively. ADB 
assistance for urban development in the PRC is in Appendix 4.   
 
19.  Lessons  Learned.  ADB-financed  urban  development  and  urban  environmental 
management projects in the PRC generally perform well. Urban development usually requires 
an integrated and multisector approach. One major lesson learned is the need for integrated 
and strategic urban planning, which is usually in the form of a well-prepared city development 
master  plan  to  guide  specific  development  activities.  The  Project  includes  several  sector 
components  (basic  urban  infrastructure,  roads,  and  district  heating).  ADB  has  engaged  in 
extensive policy dialogue with the Government and BMG to confirm that these components are 
consistent with the Baiyin Urban Development Master Plan (2001–2020) and will contribute to 
the outcome of the Project to facilitate economic transformation and improve the quality of life in 
Baiyin. Lessons identified from ADB’s post-evaluation exercises (e.g., ADB’s Special Evaluation 
Study on Urban Sector Strategy and Operations)5 highlight the importance of integrating both 
supply  and  demand  concerns  into  the  project  design.  Other  lessons  include  the  need  to 
encourage  broad  reforms,  to  introduce  appropriate  pricing  policies  and  tariff  setting  and 
adjustment mechanism to ensure cost recovery and counterpart funding for operation and 
maintenance, to consult the public and involve the community in project design, to educate the 
public on the need for environmental awareness, and to address the resettlement issue early. 
These lessons have been considered in policy dialogue with the Government and BMG, and 
incorporated in the design of the proposed Project.

B.  Outputs 
21.  The Project will have five components: (i) Southern Baiyin infrastructure, (ii) Baiyin road 
improvements, (iii) Pingchuan road improvements, (iv) district heating services, and (v) capacity 
development and institutional strengthening. The five components are summarized below. 
 
22.  Component 1: Southern Baiyin Infrastructure. Under this component, the Project will 
develop 6 km2 of industrial land with basic public infrastructure including about 24.9 km long 
primary  and  secondary  roads  and  related  water  supply  pipelines,  drainage  pipelines  and 
sewers, heating supply pipelines, optical-fabric cable and electricity distribution lines, lighting, 
and public green areas. 
 
23.  Component 2: Baiyin Road Improvements. Under this component, the Project will (i) 
construct nine new roads with a total length of 23.1 km; and (ii) build connected water supply 
pipelines, drainage pipelines, sewers, heating supply pipelines, lighting, bus rider/pedestrian 
and bicycle facilities. This component will also (i) build 14 bridges/culverts and (ii) rehabilitate 
and widen three existing roads with a total length of 6.1 km. 
 
24.  Component 3: Pingchuan Road Improvements. Under this component, the Project 
will construct (i) seven new roads with a total length of 12.6 km; and (ii) the related drainage 
pipelines, sewers, and water supply pipelines. This component will also (i) build three bridges 
and (ii) rehabilitate and widen one road 3.5 km long. 
 
25.  Component  4:  District  Heating  Services.  Under  this  component,  the  Project  will 
expand the heating service area in Baiyin district by 3.2 million square meters (m2) by (i) 
building a new heating source plant with 4x58 megawatts capacity, (ii) laying down 12.6 km of 
heat transmission pipelines, and (iii) installing 29 heat exchange stations for connection with the 
community heat distribution systems. 
 
26.  Component V: Capacity Development and Institutional Strengthening. Under this 
component, the Project will provide consulting services and financial support for BMG to: (i) 
design and introduce an EMS for SBIZ, (ii) develop a geographic information system (GIS)-
based urban planning and road and bridge management system for integrated urban transport 
planning and management, (iii) provide consulting services during project implementation, and 
(iv) provide support and training for institutional strengthening of BMG, PMO, and IAs on urban 
planning and management.   
 
C.  Special Features 
27.  Environmental Management System. A major challenge is to manage the induced 
environmental impact of the intensified industrial activities related to the development of the 
SBIZ. BMG’s initiative to develop a REIA for the SBIZ is commendable. The Project will provide 
capacity development support to help BMG establish the EMS for the SBIZ. The assistance will

7 
include (i) designing the detailed institutional structure and operational mechanism for the EMS, 
(ii)  preparing  and  developing  the  environmental  management  regulatory  framework  for  the 
industrial  zone,  (iii)  designing  and  establishing  a  centralized  environmental  management 
information system including the early warning system for emergency response, (iv) providing 
basic  environmental  monitoring  equipment,  and  (v)  providing  training  for  environmental 
management.  
 
28.  Integrated  Urban  Transport  Planning  and  Management.  Baiyin  is  at  a  relatively 
advanced stage in addressing the institutional barriers to integrated urban transport planning 
and management (para. 16). A sophisticated traffic control system has been established by the 
traffic police. The city has been chosen by the Ministry of Construction as the pilot city in Gansu 
province to apply a computer-based urban management system to improve urban planning and 
management.  A  basic  GIS-based  urban  management  system  with  limited  information  has 
already been developed. Under the Project, assistance will be provided to help BMG upgrade 
this initial GIS-based urban management system to make it an integrated urban management 
information system, which will serve, among others, as a platform to integrate urban planning, 
transport planning, and asset management. Assistance will also be provided to help establish 
the link between the traffic control system, public transport operations, and the proposed urban 
management information system. 
 
29.  Access  of  Low-Income  Families  to  District  Heating  Service. Under the planned 
economy, employers traditionally provided heating service to their employees on a cost-sharing 
basis, through community heating systems. With expansion of the district heating system, the 
employers will stop running the small community heating boilers. But this may leave the low-
income  families,  particularly  the  unemployed,  vulnerable  and  unprotected.  To  resolve  the 
problem, BMG has agreed to introduce a special heating assistance program, which will ensure 
provision of a basic volume of quality heat supply for low-income families as an essential social 
service. The program will be financed by (i) an appropriate subsidy from BMG, and (ii) the 
subsidy fund as a portion of the revenue generated by MDHC. Operational details of the 
assistance program are under study. BMG has given its assurance that the assistance program 
for low-income families will be put in operation before the full operation of the heating system 
constructed under the Project.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
 
46.  The Project will directly benefit more than 475,000 urban residents in the project areas 
through construction of urban infrastructure for economic transformation, improved urban roads, 
and expanded and enhanced district heating supply. With support from the Project, despite the 
declining share of mining-related production, Baiyin is envisaged to maintain its GDP growth at 
a double-digit annual rate from 2005 to 2015. When completed, the SBIZ is expected to provide 
more than 5,000 permanent jobs for the skilled workers whose jobs are affected by the decline 
in  the  mining  resources.  With  support  from  the  Project,  development  of  the  SBIZ  will  be 
managed  and  accomplished  by  an  effective  EMS  designed  in  accordance  with  the 
internationally  accepted  environmental  management  standards  issued  by  the  International 
Standards Organization (ISO 14000 standards).  
 
47.  The  road  improvements  component  will  improve  significantly  the  urban  transport 
situation in both Baiyin and Pingchuan districts and provide the two urban centers of Baiyin with 
the basic road framework with the capacity to meet their long-term development needs up to 
2030. The road improvements component will expand the public transport service coverage 
through increased bus lines, divert downtown traffic to the outer ring road, and reduce road 
accident fatalities from the 2005 baseline by about 10% by 2011. Through the district heating 
services component, the Project will replace 63 inefficient and highly polluting small community 
heating boilers with an efficient and environment-friendly centralized district heating system. By

13 
the year 2015, the heating service area will expand by 2.6 million m2 and benefit about 20,000 
households,  about  10%  of  whom  are  low-income  families.  The  district  heating  services 
component  will  also  help  reduce  emission  of sulfur  dioxide  by  185  tons  per  year,  reduce 
consumption of coal by 5,700 tons per year, and improve public health and indoor air quality by 
eliminating numerous indoor coal-burning stoves and facilitating the switch to district heating.   
 
B.  Social Dimensions 
 
1.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement  
 
48.  Overall, the land acquisition and resettlement impacts of the Project will be significant. In 
total, about 730.4 hectares (ha) of land will be permanently acquired by the Project, of which 
153.6  ha  or  21%  is  classified  as  farmland.  Permanent  land  acquisition  will  affect  1,619 
households or 6,272 people. The Project will also require the temporary acquisition of 13.5 ha of 
land, all of which is unoccupied state-owned land along roads to be improved. A total of 328 
households or 1,450 people will be relocated, about 61,012 m2 of residential houses will be 
demolished, 42 enterprises with a total of 1,378 employees will be affected, and 28,814 m2 of 
nonresidential  structures  will  be  dismantled.  In  addition,  some  productive  assets,  ground 
attachments,  and  public  infrastructure  facilities  will  also  be  affected.  No  ethnic  minority 
household will suffer any land acquisition or resettlement impacts.  
 
49.  For  permanent  land  acquisition,  compensation  will  be  paid  in  cash  to  the  village 
collective and the affected persons (APs). The resettlement subsidy, and compensation for 
standing crops, trees, ground attachments, and income losses suffered by enterprises will be 
paid directly to the APs. For residential houses and nonresidential houses to be demolished, 
compensation at replacement value will be paid to owners. Households who need to relocate 
will  also  receive  a  relocation  allowance.  The  measures  for  economic  rehabilitation  include 
providing jobs during the project construction and operational phases; redistributing farmland 
among affected groups wherever possible; upgrading  existing low-yield farmland to intensify 
agricultural production; developing off-farm opportunities; and providing technical training to the 
APs to increase their skills. For the vulnerable people, the respective IAs will pay an additional 
one-time grant to improve their living standards. The PMO and IA will supervise implementation 
to  ensure  the  vulnerable  persons  receive  adequate  compensation,  are  helped  in  making 
housing arrangement; and are assisted to restore their living conditions and incomes. Individual 
resettlement plans (RPs) have been prepared for each investment component under the Project 
in accordance with PRC Land Administration Law (1998), State Council Decision on Deepen 
Reform and Strictly Enforce Land Administration (2004) and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement 
Policy (1995) and associated operational procedures. RPs have been distributed to the affected 
districts, counties, villages, and APs. The resettlement information booklets were disseminated 
to the APs on 20 June 2007. The estimated cost of land acquisition and resettlement is $15 
million, equivalent to CNY116.99 million in 2007 prices, including contingencies. The summary 
RP is in Appendix 11.

C.  Financial Analysis, Sustainability, and Affordability Aspects 
 
52.  The Project is considered financially viable and sustainable. A financial impact analysis 
was  undertaken  for  the  two  revenue-generating  components  (district  heating  services  and 
Southern Baiyin infrastructure). These are further discussed in Appendix 13.  The detailed 
financial impact analysis is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
53.  MDHC is a new company that obtained from BMG a concession contract to provide 
district heating service for west Baiyin through open competition in August 2005. With initial the 
investment, MDHC has already built a heat source plant and associated transmission lines, and 
started providing heating service at an expansion rate of 200,000 m2 per year in accordance 
with its heating service expansion program. Over the 2 years of operation since November 
2005, MDHC has generated a net income of CNY4.26 million. With support from the Project, 
MDHC  will  be  able  to  accelerate  the  service  expansion  to  achieve  full  coverage  of  the 
concession area. Detailed financial analysis and assessment reveal that MDHC has sufficient 
equity fund to maintain the debt-to-equity ratio at a level not higher than 70:30 throughout the 
operation period of the Project. At the current tariff level (constant price), MDHC can maintain its 
financial  sustainability.  Investment  for  service  expansion,  heating  operation  and  system 
maintenance, and debt service can be financed by the increased revenue generated from the 
expansion of the customer base. Over the project period of 25 years, MDHC will generate a 
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of 6.4%, compared with the weighted average cost of 
capital (WACC) at 3.02%.  
 
54.  The  current  tariff  for  residential  consumers  in  Baiyin  is  CNY13  per  m2,  which  is 
considered  adequate.  It  reflects  the  local  costs  of  heating  service  and  is  generally  found 
affordable to the residents. A social survey reveals that 39% of the surveyed households would 
accept a minor increase in heating tariff for improved heating service, and 61% would not 
accept an abrupt tariff increase due to their limited resources. Of the 61%, 47.5% indicated their 
willingness to accept a gradual tariff increase if it is introduced over a 5-year period. The survey

15 
results have been discussed with BMG and MDHC. MDHC is comfortable with the current tariff 
and does not have any plan to request an increase. In the case of significant increase in the 
costs of MDHC operation inputs which may affect its financial sustainability, MDHC may request 
BMG for a tariff review. BMG will, if the request is considered reasonable, use its best efforts to 
provide support to MDHC to maintain its financial sustainability. In case tariff adjustment is 
considered  the  best  option,  BMG  will  organize  public  consultation  with  key  stakeholders 
including the representative of the low income families or other mechanisms as provided for in 
the laws and regulations on utility tariff setting before adjusting tariff. The affordability concern is 
currently concentrated on the low-income families below the MLG. Results of social survey 
indicate that heating expenditures at the current tariff level will account for about 15% of their 
income. To ensure that low-income families have access to the improved heating service, BMG 
has agreed to introduce a special heating assistance program for them. The program will 
provide a basic volume of quality heating supply for the low-income families as an essential 
social service, which will be financed by (i) an appropriate subsidy from BMG, and (ii) the 
subsidy fund as a portion of the revenue generated by MDHC (para. 29). 
 
55.  Although the BHTIP is not a self-financing entity, financial analysis has been undertaken 
for  the  Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure  component  because  this  component  will  generate 
revenues from the lease of developed industrial land. BMG will decide on a lot price at different 
levels, ranging from the minimum price for industrial land set by the Government to a level that 
achieves full cost recovery. Using the current promotion price, the financial analysis concludes 
that the Southern Baiyin infrastructure component will have an FIRR of 8.7%, compared with a 
WACC of 3.13%. 
 
56.  Results of the assessment of financial management indicate that the Project will not 
affect the financial sustainability of BMG and the IAs. BHTIP, BCCB, and MDHC have an 
adequate  internal  financial  management  system  and  enough  financial  management 
professionals to manage the Project. The PIU at PDG is relatively weak. None of the IAs has 
experience in working with international financial institutions. Special training programs have 
been arranged for the IAs with support from the project preparatory TA to help them understand 
ADB policy and project management requirements. Further training is included in the capacity 
development and institutional strengthening component of the Project.  
 
D.  Economic Aspects 
 
57.  Economic  analysis  provides  the  rationale  and  justification  for  the  Project  based  on 
policy, sector, and in-depth analysis of BMG’s strategy for economic transformation. It considers 
the Project, not as a stand-alone investment, but as an integral part of the strategy to transform 
Baiyin from a traditional mining city to a sustainable and environment-friendly urban center. A 
least-cost analysis was conducted for each of the four investment components, followed by an 
economic evaluation of each component and of the Project as a whole. For the Southern Baiyin 
infrastructure component, the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated based on 
the quantification of the incremental land value and incremental labor income. The EIRR is 
12.98%,  which  is  higher  than  the  economic  cost  of  capital  of  12%.  For  the  two  road 
improvement  components,  the  EIRR  is  14.23%  based  on  the  quantification  of  savings  on 
vehicle operation cost, savings in travel time, and reduction of road accidents. The EIRR for the 
district heating services component was calculated based on both energy efficiency benefits 
and environmental benefits under two scenarios: taking into account or not taking into account 
the reduction in environmental costs. The economic evaluation concludes that the EIRR for this 
component will be 19.70% without taking into account the reduction in environmental costs, and 
23.78%  after  taking  into  account  the  reduction  in  environmental  costs.  All  the  investment

16 
components have an EIRR higher than 12%, the economic opportunity cost of capital. The 
Project’s overall EIRR is 14.26% shows that the Project is economically viable. The summary 
economic analysis is in Appendix 14. Detailed economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix 
C. 
 
E.  Environmental Aspects 
 
58.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  was  prepared  for  the  Southern  Baiyin 
infrastructure and the district heating services components, respectively. A combined EIA was 
prepared  for  the  two  urban  road  improvements  components.  All  EIAs  were  prepared  in 
accordance with relevant laws and regulations of the PRC. All the investment components were 
examined  against  the  procedures  and  criteria  specified  in  ADB’s  Environment  Policy, 
Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines,  and  Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected 
Infrastructure Projects. In addition, a REIA was prepared for the SBIZ covering both the BHTIP 
and the 6 km2 industrial land to be developed under the Project. The REIA was prepared to 
assess and manage the induced environmental impacts that may arise from the intensified 
industrial activities as a result of the economic transformation. Extensive public consultations 
involving a survey, meetings with stakeholders, and focus group discussions were undertaken 
twice during the preparation of the EIAs and the REIA.  The EIAs and the REIA were endorsed 
by the Baiyin Environmental Protection Bureau (BEPB) and approved by the Gansu Provincial 
Environmental Protection Bureau. A copy of the REIA is in Supplementary Appendix D. 
 
59.  A summary EIA (SEIA) was circulated to ADB’s Board of Directors and posted on the 
ADB website on 29 June 2007. The SEIA confirms that all the investment components will have 
positive environmental impacts and will contribute to the strengthening of the project impact for 
a  sustainable  and  environment-friendly  urban  development  in  Baiyin.  The  district  heating 
services component will significantly improve air quality and energy efficiency in Baiyin by 
expanding the service coverage of centralized district heating to replace the inefficient and 
highly polluting small community heating boilers. Coal burned for heating will be reduced by 
5,700 tons each year, thus reducing significantly the emission of coal-based pollutants, the 
occurrence of respiratory disease during winter, and the traffic hazards caused by the transport 
of coal in urban areas. 
 
60.  The two road improvement components will provide an efficient and safe urban transport 
framework for each of the two urban centers of the city to meet their long-term development 
needs.  These  components  will  bring  environmental  benefits  by  improving  motor  vehicle 
operating efficiency, rationalizing the traffic flow passing through the city for better interaction 
between the urban transport system and the surrounding national and provincial road networks, 
reducing motor vehicle emissions, and reducing the number of road accident fatalities. The 
Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure  component  will  provide  a  platform  for  Baiyin  to  accelerate 
economic diversification and transformation to achieve the goal to build a sustainable and 
environment-friendly new Baiyin. The SEIA confirms that sufficient and appropriate mitigation 
measures to manage and alleviate the adverse environmental impacts have been introduced 
through the preparation of the REIA and EIAs. The mitigation measures are summarized in the 
EMP attached to the SEIA. The SEIA and the EMP are in Supplementary Appendix E and F, 
respectively. 
 
F.  Project Risks and Mitigation Measures 
 
61.  The  Project  does  not  have  any  unusual  technical  risks.  Conventional  engineering 
designs and technology with proven records of reliable performance are adopted for all the four

17 
investment components. Consulting services will be provided to support the PMO and IAs to 
ensure timely implementation of the Project in accordance with the design requirements and 
quality  standards.  The  SEIA  has  concluded  that  the  Project  has  met  the  environmental 
safeguard requirements of ADB and the Government of the PRC. 
 
62.  The Project will not be a success if the SBIZ, after land development, fails to attract 
investors to support the economic diversification and transformation because of a mismatch 
between the transformation strategy and Baiyin’s competitive advantages. Under the project 
preparatory TA, a strategic review was undertaken together with economic analysis to assess 
BMG’s strategy for urban economic transformation. The review confirmed the SBIZ’s advantage 
and potential to develop extended production chains for chemical research and production, and 
nonferrous processing. The involvement of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in developing and 
operating  the  BHTIP  has  also  provided  the  SBIZ  with  advanced  knowledge  inputs  and 
technology  advantages  to  attract  high  quality  investors  for  technology  upgrading.  These 
advantages have also been confirmed by the success of the BHTIP and the pipeline of new 
investors waiting for industrial land (para. 10). 
 
63.  The project risk may arise from the induced environmental impact due to the intensified 
industrial  activities  in  the  SBIZ.  To  mitigate  this  risk  in  a  systematic  manner,  BMG  has 
undertaken a REIA to assess the environmental impact from the industrial activities in both the 
existing BHTIP and the SBIZ to be developed under the Project. An EMP has been developed 
under the REIA and EIAs to mitigate the identified environmental risks. In addition to the EMP, 
BMG has decided to establish an environmental management committee (EMC) for the SBIZ to 
be chaired by the Chairman of the Economic and Finance Committee of the Baiyin People’s 
Congress. The EMC will comprise deputies of the Baiyin People’s Congress, independent 
scholars  and  environmental  specialists,  representatives  of  tenant  enterprises,  the  head  of 
BEPB, and head of Baiyin Quality Control and Production Safety Office. The EMC will provide 
policy guidance on environmental management for economic transformation at the SBIZ. Under 
the supervision of the EMC, BEPB will set a satellite office at the BHTIP to take care of day-to-
day environmental monitoring and enforcement. At the same time, each tenant enterprise at the 
SBIZ  will  be  requested  to  set  up  an  internal  environmental  management  office  or  unit 
responsible  for  the  enterprise’s  compliance  with  all  the  environmental  management 
requirements. Furthermore, consulting services will be provided under the Project to help BMG 
design the regulatory framework (including entrance criteria, detailed operational mechanism of 
the  proposed  three-tier  EMS),  and  provide  related  training  to  ensure  that  the  economic 
transformation  is  conducted  and  accomplished  in  a  sustainable  and  environment-friendly 
manner.

1.  Baiyin used to be the major nonferrous metal base in the People’s Republic of China

became exhausted and closed, the copper mine supply has dropped to 15% of the smelting and 
processing capacity. Mining of the associated mineral resources, such as lead and zinc, is also 
on a declining trend. Baiyin Nonferrous Metal Corporation (BNMC), which employs about half of

cumulative deficits. Seven of its associated companies have filed for bankruptcy. As for the 
entire city, the total industrial assets are estimated at about CNY24.0 billion, whereas the total 
debt is at about CNY19.6 billion. The city has been identified as one of the 18 most resource-
exhausted cities in the PRC, and is facing serious challenges to maintain sustainable economic 
development for the region. 
 
2.  Facing the challenges, the Baiyin Municipal Government (BMG) has been exploring the 
strategy of maintaining a sustainable economic development through economic transformation 
and diversification. Considering the special condition of rich industrial resources in Baiyin, the

development. BMG has identified four leading industries (nonferrous metal, power, chemical 
industry, and coal mining) and eight supporting industries (nonferrous metal materials, fine 
chemical  industry,  mining  material  recycling,  new  energy  materials,  machinery  and 
manufacturing,  nonmetal  material,  agricultural  product  processing,  and  tourism)  as  the 
directions of continuous economic growth. Details of the four leading industries are summarized 
below. 
 
(i)  Nonferrous  metal  industry.  Upgrade  and  improve  the  equipment  and 
technology of the traditional nonferrous metal productions, develop new alloy and 
functional materials. 
 
(ii)  Power industry. Develop hydropower, coal-based fusel power, as well as wind 
power in the region so as to develop the Baiyin area as one of the energy bases 
in the Northwest Region.    
 
(iii)  Coal mine industry. Improve the existing coal mine industry with better mining 
strategy  to  protect  the  mining  resource  and  improve  the  mining  efficiency.

(iv)  Chemical  industry.  Based  on  the  TDI  (toluene  diisovyanateI),  extend  the 
production chains to form production of MDI (diphenylmethane diisocyanate), 
PVC (polyvinyl chloride), chlor-alkali complexes, etc..   
 
3.  The plan for developing the eight supporting industries includes the following. 
 
(i)  Nonferrous metals and rare earth. Extend the production chains of the existing 
nonferrous metal including copper, aluminum, lead, as well as rare earth group to 
develop new nonferrous metal and rare earth products.

C.  Resource and Challenges in Economic Transformation 
8.  BMG has made significant progress in the economic transformation in the last 5 years. 
However, more efforts and investments will be required for sustainable economic development 
in the region. As an old industrial city, Baiyin has its own special resources that will be fully 
utilized in the economic transformation. These resources include the following:  
 
(i)  Industrial resources. Baiyin used to be the national industrial base for mining, 
with  numerous  mining  and  processing  facilities.  Even  though  some  of  the 
equipment and technologies are out-of-date, the infrastructure and facilities could 
be modified and renovated for new productions. 
 
(ii)  Land, power, and water resources. Baiyin is rich in land and power supply. It 
also  has  adequate  water  resources.  All  these  are  essential  for  industrial 
production and new economic development. 
 
(iii)  Skilled labor and human resources. Baiyin has a large pool of skilled labor and 
engineering  and  technical  personnel.  The  city  is  also  the  home  of  several 
educational and research institutes. BMG has initiated training programs that will 
teach the labor force new skills and technologies so that they can find positions 
in new productions and industries. 
 
(iv)  Location  and  transportation.  Baiyin  is  located  about  70  kilometers  (km) 
northeast of Lanzhou, the capital city of Gansu province, and is one national 
chemical production center. The two cities are connected by several national and 
provincial highways, and share one airport. An effective transportation system is 
fundamental condition in reaching out for economic development.  
 
(v)  Agricultural resource. Baiyin has abundant land resources and is suitable for 
dryland farming and horticulture. In addition to conventional farm production, new 
technologies and a diversified agroprocessing business are being developed and 
introduced in line with the ongoing economic transformation. 
 
(vi)  Government policy support. The central Government has classified Baiyin as 
one of the 18 most resource-exhausted cities. The city also benefits from the

help the city’s plan of economic transformation. 
               
9.  BMG  has  made  achievements  in  the  last  5  years,  but  the  city  is  facing  serious 
challenges to continue its economic transformation and to maintain its economic development. 
There are four challenges. 
 
1.  Exhausting Mining Resources Hindering Sustained Economic Growth 
 
10.  Many state-owned large enterprises in mining and traditional industries are deep in debt. 
BNMC, for example, had CNY4.7 billion in debt in 2005 and the liability-to-asset ratio reached 
160%. Most equipment and technologies are out-of-date, have low efficiency, use much energy, 
and  cause  heavy  pollution.  The  unemployment  rate  has  remained  high  for  years.  Many 
companies also carry heavy burdens for pensions, social welfare, unemployment benefits, etc. 
The city has made efforts to reorganize the companies of the traditional industries, develop new 
mining-related  productions,  and  shut  down  factories  that  are  no  longer  sustainable.  New 
strategy and policies will be developed to promote the market-oriented new production and the 
development  of  private-owned  enterprises  for  the  traditional  industries.  The  reform  and 
revitalization of these traditional industries are keys to a successful economic transformation. 
 
2.  Lack of New Technologies and New Investments 
 
11.  Historically, like many “company towns” developed under the planned economy, Baiyin 
depended heavily on mining and mining-related production. The local economy is isolated and 
self-independent  with  little  connection  to  the  outside  economy.  Along  with  economic 
transformation,  the  city’s  economy  had  to  adapt  itself  from  an  enclosed  production  to  a 
competitive open market. Economic survival will have to rely on improved productivity through 
adopting new technologies that have high efficiency and low energy consumption, and cause 
less environmental pollution to produce more competitive and marketable products.  Technology 
upgrading requires tremendous investment. New investments are also needed to develop new 
industries and economic sectors such as agriculture and agroprocessing, tourism, finance, and 
general services. 
 
3.  Environmental Pollution 
 
12.  Having been a mining city for more than five decades, Baiyin suffers from environmental 
pollution due to industrial emissions. In winter, smoke from heating stoves and small boilers 
contributes significantly to air pollution. In addition to the measures and actions undertaken to 
control and reduce industrial emissions (see Appendix 3), expanding the coverage of the district 
heating services is one effective means to reduce air pollution while strengthening the city’s 
capacity to provide improved heating service for its residents.  
 
4.  Low Living Standards 
 
13.  Compared with living standards in the other more developed cities in the PRC, those in 
Baiyin  are  relatively  low.  Living  standards  can  be  measured  by  household  incomes  and 
expenses; type of housing; access to roads, utilities and other infrastructure; education; medical 
care condition; cultural life; prices of foods and other goods, etc. To improve the investment 
environment, Baiyin needs to improve living standards by adding new urban infrastructure 
including roads and public facilities, increasing district heating coverage, improving schools and 
the medical care system, enriching the cultural life, etc.

D.  Proposed Project in Promoting Sustainable Urban Development 
14.  The  proposed  Project  includes  four  investment  components:  (i)  Southern  Baiyin 
infrastructure, (ii) Baiyin road improvements, (iii) Pingchuan road improvements, and (iv) district

15.   The  Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure  component  will  develop  an  additional  6  km2  of

proposed  area  is  adjacent  to  the  BHTIP,  and  is  planned  in  accordance  with  the  city’s 
development master plan. The component will provide additional sites for new production and 
industries to support the economic transformation of the city. 
 
16.  The Baiyin and Pingchuan road improvement components will construct new roads and 
improve existing roads in the urban areas in both districts. Some new roads are in the West 
Baiyin Economic Development Area and the Pingchuan Economic Development Area, which 
were developed a few years ago as part of the city’s economic transformation plan. The roads in 
the economic development areas will provide additional infrastructure to satisfy the need of the 
new plants and investments. The roads in the urban areas will improve traffic conditions and 
access for businesses and residents, improve overall urban living conditions, and promote more 
business development on the roadsides.  
 
17.  The district heating service component will increase the coverage of district heating in 
west Baiyin, and replace the existing low-efficiency and heavily polluting small heating boilers to 
save energy and reduce air pollution. This component will improve living standards and help 
promote urban development. 
 
E.  Recommendations for Continuous Economic Transformation 
1.  Role of Government, Public and Private Sector  
18.  The joint effort of the government, and the public and private sectors will help achieve 
the goal of economic transformation. BMG will provide an enabling environment for investments 
and comfortable living conditions to encourage the participation of public and private sector 
enterprises  in  economic  activities  and  to  attract  external  investors  to  the  city.  Economic 
transformation needs to follow market forces through competition to ensure its sustainability. 
 
2.  Upgraded City Infrastructure  
19.  The construction of infrastructure will provide necessary facilities for new businesses 
and production, for improving the city traffic condition and living standards, and for improving the 
overall investment environment. New infrastructure will effectively promote new investments in 
the area. The proposed Southern Baiyin infrastructure component will develop an approximately 
6 km2 area for industrial productions and new investments, which will serve as an engine to 
effectively help the city maintain sustainable economic growth. The proposed road improvement 
and district heating components will improve the urban traffic condition and living standards, 
which will facilitate the city’s economic development and attract new investments.

A.  Project Background 
1.  Baiyin city (Baiyin) is a medium-sized city located in Gansu province. The city was 
established  in  the  1950s  under  the  planned  economy  mainly  to  support  copper  mining 
production. Baiyin used to be the top copper mining area of the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), accounting for one third of national production. After continued exploitation, the copper 
mines in Baiyin have been exhausted and abandoned. Mining of the other associated minerals 
is also on the decline, with closure projected in less than two decades. Baiyin is classified by the 
Government as one of the 18 resource-exhausted mining cities. Under the 11th Five-Year 
Program (FYP) for 2006–2010, the Government has decided to provide special support, as a 
national  priority,  for  these  resource-exhausted  mining  cities  to  facilitate  their  economic 
transformation. 
 
2.  The  Project  will  provide  support  to  facilitate  economic  transformation  in  Baiyin  by 
strengthening the urban services and infrastructures, and promoting capacity development. The 
Project  has  five  components:  (i)  Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure,  (ii)  Baiyin  district  road 
improvements, (iii) Pingchuan district road improvements, (iv) Baiyin district heating services, 
and (v) capacity development and institutional strengthening. 
 
3.  Baiyin municipal government (BMG) will be the Executing Agency (EA) of the Project. 
BMG  has  established  a  project  management  office  (PMO)  responsible  for  day-to-day

will be implemented by four implementing agencies (IAs).

(i)  Component  1: Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure. Under this component, the 
Project will develop 6 square kilometers (km2) of industrial land with the basic 
public infrastructure including about 24.9 kilometers (km) long of primary and 
secondary  roads  and  related  water  supply  pipelines,  drainage  pipelines  and 
sewers, heating supply pipelines, optical-fabric cable and electricity distribution

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The proposed Project has four subprojects: (i) Southern Baiyin infrastructure; (ii) Baiyin 
district  road  improvements;  (iii)  Pingchuan  district  road  improvements;  and  (iv)  Baiyin  district 
heating services. The proposed Project will provide additional sites for new production in southern 
Baiyin, improve the road and traffic conditions in Baiyin and Pingchuan districts, and increase the 
area covered by district heating in west Baiyin. 
   
B.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Impacts 
 
2.  Overall, the land acquisition and resettlement impacts of the Project will be significant. The 
impacts by component are summarized in Table A11. In total, about 730.4 hectares (ha) of land 
will be permanently acquired by the Project, of which 21% is classified as farmland (153.6 ha). 
Permanent land acquisition will affect 1,619 households or 6,272 people. The Project will also 
require the temporary acquisition of 13.5 ha of land, all of which is unoccupied state-owned land 
along roads to be improved. A total of 328 households or 1,450 people will be relocated and about 
61,012 square meters (m2) of residential houses will be demolished. Forty-two enterprises and 
shops with a total of 1,378 employees will be affected, and 28,814 m2 of nonresidential structures 
will  be  dismantled.  In  addition,  some  productive  assets,  ground  attachments,  and  public 
infrastructure and facilities will be affected including electric poles, toilets, fences, hand-pumped 
wells, doors, pigpens, platform, barns, greenhouses, concrete and asphalt roads, and trees. Of the 
total affected population, 1,619 households or 6,272 people are rural residents, and 1,584 are 
urban residents, owners of structures with or without certificates, private business owners, and staff. 
There are no ethnic minority people among the affected persons (APs). The resettlement plans 
(RPs) for the components will be updated based on a detailed design and submitted to the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for approval during implementation. 
 
C.  Policy and Legal Framework 
 
3.  The compensation for permanent land loss is based on the Land Administration Law of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) (1998) and the State Council Decision to Deepen Reform and 
Strictly Enforce Land Administration (Document 28 dated November 2004). House demolition is 
based on the Provincial and Municipal Urban Housing Demolishment Administration Regulations. 
The RPs for the investment components comply with PRC laws and regulations of resettlement 
and  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995).  Based  on  consultations  with  local 
governments and those affected, a set of compensation standards was adopted by the city project 
management  office  (PMO)  and  implementing  agencies  (IAs).  The  resettlement  principles 
established for the Project are as follows: (i) land acquisition and involuntary resettlement should 
be avoided or minimized, where feasible, through alternative design options; (ii) compensation and 
entitlements must be based on replacement value and must be adequate to allow those affected to 
at least maintain their preproject standard of living, with the prospect of improvement; (iii) land 
temporarily occupied and the period of disruption are to be kept to a minimum; (iv) all the APs, 
legal  and  illegal,  are  to  be  taken  into  consideration  and  accounted  for;  (v)  the  per  capita 
landholding after land acquisition should be sufficient to maintain the previous livelihood standard; 
(vi) where land allocation per capita is not sufficient to maintain the previous livelihood standards, 
other income-generating activities will be provided; (vii) a preferential policy will be applied to

1.  Economic  analysis  was  conducted  for  each  investment  component  and  the  Project 
following the steps of demand forecast, least-cost analysis, assessment of economic costs and 
benefits, and calculation of the economic internal rate of return (EIRR). Project risks were

A.  Least-Cost Analysis 
 
2.  The  Southern  Baiyin  infrastructure  component  is  to  expand  the  Southern  Baiyin 
industrial zone (SBIZ) by developing 6 square kilometers (km2) of industrial land. Given its 
geographic location, the SBIZ has only two alternatives for expansion: to the west or to the 
south. Expansion to the south is the least-cost option, because it will enable the SBIZ to better 
utilize existing urban infrastructure including the road network, wastewater treatment facilities, 
and power supply system, and will require less land acquisition and resettlement. Analyses for 
the  two  road  improvements  components  were  undertaken  to  compare  two  alternatives:  (i) 
building  a systematic road  transport  framework  for long-term  urban  development  (with  the 
Project), or (ii) relying on strengthened road maintenance of the existing urban roads (without 
the Project). 
 
3.  Least-cost  analysis  for  district  heating  services  component  compared  the  costs  of 
alternative heating systems including individual electric boiler (1.8 megawatts [MW]), individual 
gas-fired heating facility (7 MW), small coal-fired community heating boiler (less than 7 MW), 
and large coal-fired heating boiler (58 MW). These alternatives are technically feasible but 
mutually exclusive for the Project. Alternative analysis concludes that centralized district heating 
based on a large coal-fired heating boiler is the least-cost option. Alternative analysis took into 
consideration the observations that (i) coal will remain as the main source of energy for heating 
supply because Gansu province is short of gas or oil supply; and (ii) power-heat co-generation 
will not be financially viable due to the adequate supply of electricity power on the local market, 
which leaves no room for a relatively small power and heat co-generation plant to survive 
without a subsidy.
